message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) syndrome, which is characterized by congenital absence of the uterus and upper part (2/3) of the vagina. This is caused by agenesis of the paramesonephric duct. Deficiency of 5-alpha reductase and deficiency of 17-alpha-hydroxylase are causes of disorders of sexual development, but they would present with different symptoms. Monosomy of sex chromosomes (Turner syndrome) can also cause amenorrhea, but patients with Turner syndrome have underdeveloped ovaries and secondary sex characteristics.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of normal breast development and pubic and axillary hair suggests that there is sufficient estrogen in the body. The normal ovaries and atretic uterus suggest that the cause of the patient's symptoms is agenesis of the paramesonephric duct. This means that the Müllerian ducts fail to develop properly and thus, the patient does not have a uterus or a fully formed vagina. Deficiency of 5-alpha reductase and deficiency of 17-alpha-hydroxylase would present with other symptoms like ambiguous genitalia and hormonal imbalances. Monosomy of sex chromosomes (Turner Syndrome) would present with additional symptoms like short stature, a broad chest and webbing of the neck.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of pubic and axillary hair suggests normal levels of androgens, ruling out deficiency of 5-alpha reductase and deficiency of 17-alpha-hydroxylase. The absence of a uterine cavity suggests agenesis of the paramesonephric duct, which in turn leads to the failure of the development of the uterus and the upper two-thirds of vagina. Monosomy of sex chromosomes (Turner syndrome) would also present with amenorrhea, but typically with primary amenorrhea and other physical features such as short stature and wide-spaced nipples, which are not mentioned in the clinical scenario.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of normal breast development and coarse pubic and axillary hair indicates normal levels of circulating estrogen and androgens. The blind vaginal pouch suggests that the vagina did not develop correctly, pointing towards agenesis of the paramesonephric duct. Deficiencies of 5-alpha reductase and 17-alpha-hydroxylase do not typically present with primary amenorrhea. Monosomy of sex chromosomes (Turner syndrome) can also cause primary amenorrhea, but the physical findings described in the question stem do not fit with this diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of lack of menstrual period, blind vaginal pouch and normal ovaries suggest that the patient has Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser Syndrome (MRKH), which is caused by agenesis of the paramesonephric duct. Deficiency of 5-alpha reductase and deficiency of 17-alpha-hydroxylase are conditions that affect testosterone production and cause abnormalities in sexual development, but do not cause MRKH. Monosomy of sex chromosomes would cause Turner syndrome, which typically presents with secondary sexual characteristics that are not fully developed.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has normal breast development and pubic/axillary hair, which indicates normal estrogen production. However, she has a blind vaginal pouch and atretic uterus, which suggests that her paramesonephric (Mullerian) duct did not develop properly. This is most likely due to agenesis of the paramesonephric duct. Deficiency of 5-alpha reductase or 17-alpha-hydroxylase would affect hormone production and cause other symptoms. Monosomy of sex chromosomes would cause a variety of developmental abnormalities.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The blind vaginal pouch and normal ovaries but atretic uterus suggest agenesis of the paramesonephric duct. Deficiency of 5-alpha reductase and deficiency of 17-alpha-hydroxylase are associated with ambiguous genitalia. Monosomy of sex chromosomes (Turner syndrome) typically presents with streak ovaries and an underdeveloped uterus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of normal breast development, coarse pubic and axillary hair, and an atretic uterus with blind vaginal pouch suggests a Mullerian agenesis, also known as Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome. This is caused by agenesis of the paramesonephric duct. Deficiencies of 5-alpha reductase and 17-alpha-hydroxylase are unrelated to this condition, and monosomy of sex chromosomes would result in primary amenorrhea with underdeveloped secondary sexual characteristics.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) syndrome which is characterized by the absence of the uterus and the upper part of the vagina. Among the options, only agenesis of the paramesonephric duct is associated with this condition. Deficiency of 5-alpha reductase is associated with incomplete virilization of external genitalia, and monosomy X is associated with Turner syndrome. Deficiency of 17-alpha-hydroxylase can cause ambiguous genitalia in females.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s normal breast development and pubic and axillary hair suggest that she has gone through puberty, but the blind vaginal pouch suggests a lack of a uterus and upper vagina. This is consistent with agenesis of the paramesonephric ducts, which develop into the female reproductive system.
